DataElement.preferredName: Patient Vital Signs Physical Examination Unit of Measure
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the measurement units for each vital sign physical examination (i.e., height, weight, etc.).

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information relating to a physical examination (a systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion, and auscultation, aimed to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for individual's health assessment) of a patient's vital signs (a set of tests that analyze vital signs including temperature, respiratory rate, heart beat (pulse), and blood pressure).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A person who requires medical care.

Concepts.definition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.

Property.preferredDefinition: Definition not available.:Examination of the body by auscultation, palpation, percussion, inspection, and olfaction.  (Taber's)

Concepts.definition: A systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation. The purpose is to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for an individual's health assessment.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Vital Signs Physical Examination Unit of Measure
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the enumerated list of unit of measure types for physical examinations of vital signs.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A centimeter is a basic unit of length in the former CGS version of metric system, equal to one hundredth of a meter or approximately 0.393 700 787 inch.

Concepts.definition: A basic unit of length in the former CGS version of metric system, equal to one hundredth of a meter or approximately 0.393 700 787 inch.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The basic SI unit of mass.  It is defined as the mass of an international prototype in the form of a platinum-iridium cylinder kept at Sevres in France. It is the only basic unit still defined in terms of a material object, and also the only one with a prefix [kilo] already in place. A kilogram is equal to 1,000 grams and 2.204 622 6 pounds.

Concepts.definition: A basic SI unit of mass. It is defined as the mass of an international prototype in the form of a platinum-iridium cylinder kept at Sevres in France. A kilogram is equal to 1,000 grams and 2.204 622 6 pounds.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Square meter is the SI unit of area measurement equal to a square whose sides are one meter long. Square meter is equal to 10,000 square centimeters; 0.01 ares; 1.196 square yards; 10.76 square feet; 1550 square inches.

Concepts.definition: A SI unit of area measurement equal to a square whose sides are one meter long. Square meter is equal to 10,000 square centimeters; 0.01 are; 1.196 square yards; 10.76 square feet; 1550 square inches.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The number of heartbeats measured per minute time.

Concepts.definition: The number of heartbeats measured per minute time.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The number of breaths (inhalation and exhalation) taken per minute time.

Concepts.definition: The number of breaths (inhalation and exhalation) taken per minute time.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A unit of temperature of the temperature scale designed so that the freezing point of water is 0 degrees and the boiling point is 100 degrees at standard atmospheric pressure. The current official definition of the Celsius sets 0.01 C to be at the triple point of water and a degree to be 1/273.16 of the difference in temperature between the triple point of water and absolute zero. One degree Celsius represents the same temperature difference as one Kelvin.

Concepts.definition: A unit of temperature of the temperature scale designed so that the freezing point of water is 0 degrees and the boiling point is 100 degrees at standard atmospheric pressure. The current official definition of the Celsius sets 0.01 C to be at the triple point of water and a degree to be 1/273.16 of the difference in temperature between the triple point of water and absolute zero. One degree Celsius represents the same temperature difference as one Kelvin.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Percentage; a fraction or ratio with 100 understood as the denominator.

Concepts.definition: A fraction or ratio with 100 understood as the denominator.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A traditional unit of length equal to 2.54 centimeters.

Concepts.definition: A traditional unit of length equal to 1/12 of a foot or 2.54 centimeters.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The traditional unit of mass. By international agreement, one avoirdupois pound is equal to exactly 0.453 592 37 kilogram, 16 ounces, or 1.215 28 troy pounds.

Concepts.definition: The traditional unit of mass. By international agreement, one avoirdupois pound is equal to exactly 0.453 592 37 kilogram, 16 ounces, or 1.215 28 troy pounds.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A unit of pressure equal to 0.001316 atmosphere and equal to the pressure indicated by one millimeter rise of mercury in a barometer at the Earth's surface.

Concepts.definition: A non-SI unit of pressure equal to 133,332 Pa or 1.316E10-3 standard atmosphere. Use of this unit is generally deprecated by ISO and IUPAC.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The Fahrenheit temperature scale is named after the German physicist Gabriel Fahrenheit (1686-1736), who proposed it in 1724.  In this scale, the freezing point of water is 32 degrees Fahrenheit and the boiling point is 212 degrees, placing the boiling and melting points of water 180 degrees apart. In this scale a degree Fahrenheit is 5/9ths of a kelvin (or of a degree Celsius), and minus 40 degrees Fahrenheit is equal to minus 40 degrees Celsius.

Concepts.definition: A unit of temperature of the temperature scale designed so that the freezing point of water is 32 degrees and the boiling point is 212 degrees, placing the boiling and melting points of water 180 degrees apart. One degree Fahrenheit is 5/9ths of a kelvin (or of a degree Celsius), and minus 40 degrees Fahrenheit is equal to minus 40 degrees Celsius.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the units of measure for assessment results and dosing.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Unit of Measure; a predetermined quantity (as of length, time, or heat) adopted as a standard of measurement.

Concepts.definition: A named quantity in terms of which other quantities are measured or specified, used as a standard measurement of like kinds.

ValueDomain.origin: AMC CRF:AIDS Malignancy Consortium Case Report Form

DataElement.origin: AMC CRF:AIDS Malignancy Consortium Case Report Form
